Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z: \\mathbb{C} \\rightarrow \\mathbb{C} \\) defined by \\( z(t) = e^{iAt} \\) where \\( A \\) is a real constant matrix and \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit. The function defines wave-like motion in the complex plane over time. An integral transformation \\( T \\) defined by \\( Tz(t) = \\int_0^t e^{iB\\tau} z(\\tau) d\\tau \\) where \\( B \\) is another real constant matrix, is applied to study its effect.

If the function \\( z(t) \\) is defined at time t = 0 and allowed to evolve according to its rule without further modification, will \\( z(T) \\) at any time T be influenced by the matrix \\( B \\)?
Explanation: Without any intervention, the evolution of \\( z(t) \\) is wholly independent of \\( B \\) and solely depends on \\( A \\). The trajectory of \\( z(t) \\) in the complex plane is governed by the exponentiation with \\( iA \\), with \\( B \\) playing no role.
